node.title: Spatially dependent anisotropic elastic material
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose community,
I would like to simulate a material having anisotropic and spatially dependent elastic properties. In particular, let’s take the transverse isotropic case. In “ComputeElasticityTensor”, I need to specify C_ijkl = '1111, 1122, 1133, 3333, 2323’. Let’s suppose that I know how the 5 terms depend on (x, y, z) via 5 different functions of (x, y, z).
In practice, I am looking at the generalisation of the pair “ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor” and “ComputeVariableIsotropicElasticityTensor” to the case of anisotropic elasticity, but I could not find a “ComputeVariableElasticityTensor” that generalises “ComputeElasticityTensor”.
ComputeElasticityTensor expects C_ijkl supplied as a std::vector. I could not find a way to define such vector in terms of an array of functions each returning a double. Would this do the trick, and how do I achieve this?
I also tried to define C_ijkl in a similar way as GenericFunctionRankTwoTensor is defined in the documentation:
[./tensor]
  type = GenericFunctionRankTwoTensor
  tensor_name = function
  tensor_functions = 'fcn_00 fcn_01 fcn_02 fcn_10 fcn_11 fcn_12 fcn_20 fcn_21 fcn_22'
  outputs = all
[../]

But could not find an equivalent such as "GenericFunction" array of doubles instead of a tensor.
Any help would be much appreciated.
Thank you.
Luca

Hello
The format needed for this material property might not exactly exist in the framework yet, but it should be fairly easy to add.
So each component is a function, and you want to be defining a tensor, but with symmetry properties?
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume,
Yes. For instance, quoting from the current documentation on ComputeElasticityTensor, one can define:
[./elasticity_tensor]
#Material constants selected to match isotropic lambda and shear modulus case
type = ComputeElasticityTensor
C_ijkl = '1022726 113636 113636 1022726 454545'
fill_method = axisymmetric_rz
[../]
But this does not work if I want the '1022726 113636 ... ' to be a function of (x, y, z), rather than a vector of constants.
In addition to being able to define a tensor whose components are functions, I would need to be able to pass this tensor to the C_ijkl parameter of ComputeElasticityTensor.
Thanks,
Luca

Yeah this isnt going work too easily from the existing code, because this is how the tensor is assigned:
  _elasticity_tensor[_qp] = _Cijkl;

so thee _Cijkl has to be already filled with Real values.
But that doesnt make it impossible to add a ComputeFunctionElastictyTensor, it just adds an extra step.

add a new class member _Cijkl_functions, which is a tensor of functions
change the input parameter to a vector of functions, use the same fill method (it's templated) to fill the tensor of functions
at evaluation time, use the tensor of functions to fill the _Cijkl tensor of Real, going component by component
set the elasticity tensor the same way as above, using the computed _Cijkl

node.title: Segmentation error in peacock
node.bodyText:
I am new to moose. I am trying the learn it through the tutorials. Currently, I am trying to run darcy_thermo_mech step 1 simulation.
Unfortunately, Peacock does not work. I tried to open the result file after running the simulation via command line and I tried to open the input file via peacock and run the simulation there and also view the result inside peacock.
I explain the problem here.
If I want to open the result with peacock, I use the following command:
/moose/python/peacock/peacock -r step1_out.i
But, it shows the following error.
Automatic executable search disabled
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
If I want to open the input file with peacock, I use the following command:
/moose/python/peacock/peacock -i step1.i
In this case, peacock opens. For the first time when I ran the simulation within peacock it ran and then when I wanted to view the result. peacock closed suddenly.
The command line message including error is folllowing:
Running command: /home/amajumda/projects_moose/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/step01_diffusion/darcy_thermo_mech-opt Outputs/csv=true -i peacock_run_exe_tmp_step1.i
Working directory: /home/amajumda/projects_moose/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/step01_diffusion/problems
Finished: Exit code: 0
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
From the second time onwards, peacock opens and the simulation don't run.
The command line error is the following:
Found executable: /home/amajumda/projects_moose/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/step01_diffusion/darcy_thermo_mech-opt
Exodus filenames: ['peacock_run_exe_tmp_step1_out.e']
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
What operating system are you running?
Sorry for late reply. I am using linux. Distribution is ubuntu 20.04.02 LTS.
Does the input file run from the command line without Peacock? Are you running on a remote machine?
Yes. Everything is running without Peacock. No, I am not running on a remote machine. I am running on my own laptop.
Could you please run this in a debugger and post the backtrace
Could you please share, how to run in debugger mode? Is it there in the help section of moose?

You should be able to adapt these instructions for Moose to peacock.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html

I tried to run the file, that you shared. It is showing the following error.
2021-04-27 17:43:39.837 (   0.079s) [          3C3F40]  vtkExodusIIReader.cxx:1662   ERR| vtkExodusIIReaderPrivate (0x55d23f1a1130): Could not read nodal result variable pressure.
I did the following:

I created a file named vtkChecker.py.
copying the content from the link
changed the variables filename to 'step1_out.e' and nodal_var to 'pressure'. pressure is the variable that I am also seeing in paraview.
I add execute permission for the file 'vtkChecker.py'
I run it using ./vtkCheck.py for the first time and then python3 ./vtkChecker.py for the second time. Both show the same error.

Additionally it opens this window.
"pressure" might not be nodal, but it looks like VTK is working

I'm in a similar state.  I came to see if there was any new discussions regarding segfaults with peacock.  I just started going through the examples.  I tried to run peacock with both the test app and the ex01 app.  I followed the online documents maybe a month ago for miniconda.  Tonight I did a git clone and continued following the instructions, I double checked my terminal history to verify I didn't skip a step.  I've tried starting peacock through the PATH variable and with an absolute path to moose/python/peacock.  I am local on MacOS big sur 11.2.1.  The ex01 makes and iterates successfully.  I just did a pip install pyqt5 to satisfy peacock dependencies.  It begins opening a window before the very brief segmentation fault message comes back.
I don't think Peacock currently supports Big Sur. @aeslaughter will know
Unfortunately it does not... There is a PR (a rather old one) in place that is supposed to fix the issue: #17106

Peacock should be supported now @EricPgh
The necessary python packages were updated

node.title: Update and build libmesh failing on HPC cluster
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
I'm trying to install MOOSE on a cluster for local use (not cluster wide). I've followed the instructions on the website (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html) except for the fact that the HPC already has PETSc installed, so I just load the module in using module load cray-petsc. I also load in cray-mpich and cray-tpsl.
Libmesh fails to build with the following message:
Makefile:28457: recipe for target 'src/systems/libmesh_opt_la-system_projection.lo' failed make[1]: *** [src/systems/libmesh_opt_la-system_projection.lo] Error 1 make[1]: Leaving directory '/group/project/software/moose/libmesh/build' Makefile:32536: recipe for target 'all-recursive' failed make: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
This happens using gcc 6.1.0 and gcc 7.2.0 (in case that is helpful). Hopefully someone here has an idea of what's going wrong, I'm totally stumped!

Hello
There should be a build log around, a file named config.log. Could you please upload it here
Guillaume

Hello
Any update on this?

node.title: Grain tracker with ebsd reader and nucleation causes error
node.bodyText:
Hello Everyone,
I mentioned this problem in another discussion about the grain tracker, but it seemed divergent from the issue in that thread. I want to load a grain structure with the ebsd reader then model dynamic recrystallization using the Grain Tracker and Discrete Nucleation. Everything seems to progress fine until a nucleus meets the requirements to be remapped with the grain tracker, then an error is produced from the ebsd reader:

*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "ebsd_reader", of type "EBSDReader".
Error! Index out of range in EBSDReader::indexFromIndex(), index: 10 size: 9

The system starts with 9 grains, adding a 10th grain breaks breaks the ebsd reader. Attached is a reduced input file based on the grain_tracker_ebsd test in the phase field module and the ebsd file from that test, which will produce the error. Hopefully combining these features is possible and I am just missing something, any help would be appreciated.
Floyd
grain_tracker_ebsd_nucleation_error.txt
ebsd_9.txt

@FHilty can you try setting
[ebsd_reader]
type = EBSDReader
execute_on = INITIAL
[]
[ebsd]
type = PolycrystalEBSD
coloring_algorithm = jp
ebsd_reader = ebsd_reader
execute_on = INITIAL
[]
The ebsd reader should not be running past the zeroth timestep, I think that is what is causing your issue.

When I commented following section then your input file is working
[phi1]
  type = OutputEulerAngles
  euler_angle_provider = ebsd_reader
  output_euler_angle = phi1
  grain_tracker = grain_tracker
  variable = phi1
[]
[Phi]
  type = OutputEulerAngles
  euler_angle_provider = ebsd_reader
  output_euler_angle = Phi
  grain_tracker = grain_tracker
  variable = Phi
[]
[phi2]
  type = OutputEulerAngles
  euler_angle_provider = ebsd_reader
  output_euler_angle = phi2
  grain_tracker = grain_tracker
  variable = phi2
[]

Here is the animation video:

  
    
    

    Nucleation-1.mP4

That was indeed the culprit, thank you very much Vishal!
Floyd

@FHilty If you are planning to perform large scale simulations then you should use @chaitanyaBhave26 ' s modified EBSDReader, which is more memory efficient compared to the current EBSDReader.  Otherwise, current EBSDReader is good for small system size and number of grains.
In the near term the systems will be small, but i expect to have to go up to 100+ grains eventually. I will keep that in mind, thank you!

I have attached the configure.log file.
configure.log
I think it might be an issue with SLURM and job allocation? I used the slurm srun command to request and interactive session using one node. But I am not sure how to continue.
I appreciate any advice or suggestions.

Hello
What exactly did you type for srun, and by default how many cores do you get with one node?
It seems to be complaining because it only has one MPI slot and it needs two for the tests. You can change the number of slots (oversuscribe) with the advice given here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35704637/mpirun-not-enough-slots-available
Guillaume

The specific srun command from above error is just:
 srun --account=myaccount --partition=mypartition --x11 --pty --mem=4G bash
This defaults to one core on one node.
There are 40 cores per node:
$ grep -c processor /proc/cpuinfo
40

Thank you for referring me to that stackexchange I do think that is the issue. However ,the tests still fail.
I have tried a couple different solutions but still get the same error:


Added the --oversubscribe flag to the /src/snes/tutorial/makefile in the mpi compilation step. This may not be the correct place for this flag so that may be the problem. I have attached the makefile that I edited below.
makefile_oversubscribe.txt


Added the -hostfile flag in the same place. And added localhost slots=1,2,...4 etc


Added both --oversubscribe and -hostfile to  /src/snes/tutorial/makefile


Invoked a variety of srun environments



-n 2
-N 1 --cpus-per-task=2
*-n 2 --cpus-per-task=2


Tried running it from sbatch using these settings
#!/bin/bash
  #SBATCH --nodes=1            ### Number of Nodes
  #SBATCH --ntasks-per-node=2 ### Number of tasks (MPI processes)
  #SBATCH --out=out.out
  #SBATCH --err=err.out
  module load gcc/7.3
  module load openmpi
  
  
  srun ./test_petsc.sh





the test_petsc.sh file is just  make PETSC_DIR=/home/akubo/myprojects/moose_models/moose/scripts/../petsc PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose

Still getting the same error. I think that I am on the right track right now but maybe I am looking at the wrong makefile.
Really appreciate your help with this.
These are the modules loaded:
Currently Loaded Modules:
  1) slurm/19.05   2) cmake/3.12.4   3) gcc/7.3   4) openmpi/2.1

Hello
I m actually not sure we are on the right track with the oversuscribing now. Finding threads that say this is an OpenFabrics issue
https://users.open-mpi.narkive.com/ha9nLcfD/ompi-error-with-open-mpi-2-0-0-error-obtaining-device-attributes-for-mlx5-0-errno-says-cannot
And this
open-mpi/ompi#8260
Could be tied to openmpi? 2.1 is fairly old. Do you have newer modules available on this cluster?
Guillaume

I found this advice on using the PETSC tests with SLURM and tried it but got the same results
https://researchcomputing.princeton.edu/support/knowledge-base/petsc
Could be tied to openmpi. I have contacted my cluster admin to see about different versions.
Thank you,
Allison
any update on this?

I was able to get PETSC and libmesh compiled with the following modules
$ module list

Currently Loaded Modules:
  1) slurm/19.05   2) gcc/7.3   3) mpich/3.2   4) python3/3.6.5   5) cmake/3.15.4


Thank you for your help!

node.title: mamba install error
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am reinstalling conda/mamba from scratch on a remote machine. I have installed conda and i installed mamba using conda with the following commands conda install mamba -n base -c conda-forge. I have added the inl channel and when i try to install moose-tools and moose-libmesh but i get the following error.
Looking for: ['moose-tools', 'moose-libmesh']

pkgs/main/linux-64       [====================] (00m:00s) No change
pkgs/main/noarch         [====================] (00m:00s) No change
pkgs/r/linux-64          [====================] (00m:00s) No change
pkgs/r/noarch            [====================] (00m:00s) No change
public/linux-64          [====================] (00m:00s) No change
public/noarch            [====================] (00m:00s) No change
Encountered problems while solving:
  - nothing provides gxx_linux-64 9.3.0 h0d07fa4_29 needed by moose-tools-2021.07.13-py39haff3c87_0
  - nothing provides libpng 1.6.37 hed695b0_2 needed by moose-libmesh-2021.06.30-build_1

Running mamba list has the following packages.
# packages in environment at /home/qt5/miniconda3/envs/moose:
#
# Name                    Version                   Build  Channel
_libgcc_mutex             0.1                        main
_openmp_mutex             4.5                       1_gnu
_sysroot_linux-64_curr_repodata_hack 3                   haa98f57_10
binutils_impl_linux-64    2.35.1               h27ae35d_9
binutils_linux-64         2.35.1              h454624a_30
gcc_impl_linux-64         9.3.0               h6df7d76_17
gcc_linux-64              9.3.0               h1ee779e_30
gxx_impl_linux-64         9.3.0               hbdd7822_17
gxx_linux-64              9.3.0               h7e70986_30
kernel-headers_linux-64   3.10.0              h57e8cba_10
ld_impl_linux-64          2.35.1               h7274673_9
libgcc-devel_linux-64     9.3.0               hb95220a_17
libgcc-ng                 9.3.0               h5101ec6_17
libgomp                   9.3.0               h5101ec6_17
libstdcxx-devel_linux-64  9.3.0               hf0c5c8d_17
libstdcxx-ng              9.3.0               hd4cf53a_17
sysroot_linux-64          2.17                h57e8cba_10

Thanks,
Zack

Interesting. These are very old versions. We're certainly into the early 2022's on moose-libmesh. What instructional page were you following? Perhaps we have a bad page lingering around that we need to deal with!

Installation from scratch shouldnt lead to an old version, this is indeed interesting.
@milljm what's the latest version of moose-libmesh? Having an update issue as well and I want to try a new solution.

@milljm I went to the moose install doc and saw that some changes were made. Mainly that there is a direct install of mamba and not an install of conda first then having conda install mamba. I thought this was kinda weird so i went to the mamba site. They said that i could still install mamba using conda so i just installed conda then used conda to install mamba. I could have messed up by installing an old version of conda? Im gonna try installing conda again to fix this issue. I did see on the moose install guide that they still say conda when referring to a lot of things, which i think is a typo considering they moose now recommends a direct install of mamba.
Is there a reason that moose now recommends directly installing mamba and not conda?
Ok so i followed the install guide to the T and it looks like everything installed right. I still think this is kinda a strange error but i guess this is why you follow the install guide.

Oh I see, this is truly a 're-install' attempt. I think I got confused with the phrase 'from scratch' :)
In this case, I am willing to bet there is a pre-existing 'moose' Conda environment stuck on some old versions of our packages. It happens, and not your fault! What I'd like you to do, is delete this stuck environment:
conda activate base
conda env remove -n moose
and then create it again.
mamba create -n moose moose-libmesh moose-tools
I believe that will bring you up to latest versions.

node.title: libMesh Update (2022.01.19) and January 2022 News
node.bodyText:
A new libMesh made its way to the MOOSE master branch in January. For those using the conda packages, please perform
conda update --all

in your MOOSE conda environment. The appropriate moose-libmesh package version should be 2022.01.19. For those using the the libMesh submodule, please run in the moose/scripts directory
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh

after updating your copy of MOOSE.
More details on the content of this update can be found in the January 2022 Newsletter. If issues are experienced in updating from earlier versions of the moose-libmesh package, please see the comment in #19532 for information on how to fix your environment.

node.title: PorousFlow Permeable BCs
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I want to simulate a porous body which is subjected to a ramp displacement (FunctionDirichletBC) at the top. The sides and bottom are confined, the top is unconfined so fluid flow should occur there, but the FunctionDirichletBC makes it impermeable. How can I make my BC permeable for the fluid?

Short answer: see https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/boundaries.html
Longer answer: this is difficult both conceptually and numerically/physically.  That is, you are coupling the porous flow within your sample to some other physics that governs the fluid's physics in the atmosphere.  The rate of fluid transfer between the two obviously depends on the physics in the atmosphere.  So what is that physics?   You have to decide, and the above link gives you some suggestions.  For the type of problem that i'm often doing recently, i make a thin,  permeable layer and then use a PorousFlowOutflow BC, but in the past i've used the PorousFlowSink to good effect
Thank, it works now with PorousFlowOutflow. I tried that before and it didn't work. Guess I just got some settings wrong the first time.

node.title: Slanted bicrystal Grain boundary
node.bodyText:
Good afternoon,
I hope that you are doing well.
I was wondering if there were any way to have an initial condition with a slanted boundary between two crystals; with an inclination at various degrees, but still able to use grain tracker. I have been trying to apply the various Phase Filed initial conditions from MOOSE to get that, but I keep failing.
Thank you in advance for the help.

The short answer probably is that no, we don't have a way to specify GB angle for bicrystal structure. Having said that,  if you create a bicrystal with any of the polycrystal initial conditions, you will be able to generate a slanted GB (I have done this with Voronoi IC). You might not have precise control over the angle though. Alternatively, you can derive from https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/ics/BoundingBoxIC.html and create a new initial condition.

I see. I will try as you suggested.
Thank you for the answer.

node.title: Stochastic Tools module, POD-RB for generalized eigenvalue problems?
node.bodyText:
I'm looking into using the Stochastic Tools module for generating surrogate POD-RB models for neutron diffusion problems similar to the example here. However, I see that the listed requirement is for the problem to be a scalar-valued linear steady-state PDE with a suitable affine decomposition, meaning a problem like A(mu) u = b(mu). I'd like to do this as an eigenvalue problem with fission, so a problem of the form A(mu) u = lambda B(mu) u - examples like this using POD/PGD have appeared in the literature, and I've implemented it outside of MOOSE.
I understand this is not currently available functionality - before I go too deep down the rabbit hole of trying to make modifications on my branch (and likely getting it wrong right away)... is this feasible with the current implementation/is there any advice on where to start looking to make changes/additions? Thanks in advance!
@zachmprince
@somu15 @zachmprince could you please share your comments on this?

@GiudGiud Thank you for doubling back on this - I think this question can be resolved though, as I was able to get this working for myself without too much issue (turned out to be much simpler than expected).
